title: 15+ Free Certifications To Gain High-Income Skills In 2025
description: Gain one of six in-demand, high-paying skills of 2025 with one of these 15+ free certificates/courses, covering MS Office to cloud computing. Build your competitive edge.
content:
You’ve seen it all over the headlines. AI is axing entry-level jobs. Computer science graduates who’ve been sold the dream of completing university and walking straight into their dream role at a Big Tech employer, are seeing their dreams shattered right before their very eyes.

The job market is relentless, and AI is making it more difficult than ever for the class of 2025 to begin their careers.

Unfortunately, it takes more than entry-level skill or merely a degree to survive the market right now. You need to know what skill sets employers are specifically needing the most in the talent market right now, so you can meet their demand, become irreplaceable by AI, and make yourself indispensable.

Employers are reporting significant skills shortages and skills gaps within different markets and industries, from software development to data analytics to design, product management, marketing, and even customer success.

For example, the most critical gap within the software development field is cloud platforms, with only 0.07% of developer resumes mentioning this skill, despite 3.98% of job posts requiring it, according to Huntr’s recent Job Search Trends report of Q2 2025.

Similarly, within data analytics, cloud platforms again emerged as the most significant skills shortage, hindering employers from tapping into high-skilled talent and reducing innovation.

In this article, you’ll learn the top skills gaps that Huntr’s report highlights, and armed with these insights, you’ll also discover how to upskill in these core areas for free, so you can gain a competitive edge and do what at least 90% of job search candidates are not doing right now.

These small tweaks could make all the difference between you landing on a thick “rejected" resume pile, or securing an interview and final offer, and even being chased down by employers because of your rare expertise.

The Biggest Skills Gaps Right Now

According to Huntr’s report, these are the competencies with the most significant skills shortages in the labor market right now And they’re high-income skills too, with most paying lucratively in roles with average salaries of $100,000 or more (like in UX design and product management). Employers are scrambling to fill these and related roles, but aren’t able to adequately fill them due to lack of access or availability of talent skilled in these very areas:
• Administrative--Microsoft Office (employers are looking for advanced-level proficiency, especially with Copilot on the scene, not just basic email typing and PowerPoint templates)

What’s worrying about this skills gap (and you should be alarmed too) is that all of these skills can be acquired easily and inexpensively…meaning you don't even need a degree to acquire them.

You can undertake intense technical training, or learn via a specialised course or bootcamp, and gain the necessary expertise which will put you way ahead of the rest who haven’t had such training. (More on that below.)

One thing that strikes me the most about this list of in-demand skills, is portfolio skills, which is essentially revealing that employers acknowledge that job search candidates within the design industry, i.e. fashion, graphic design, etc., are failing to create or design portfolios in a way that truly sells them.

This is a very simple error that can easily be solved, but something that many job seekers in this field unfortunately miss. Simply not having a portfolio, or one that clearly articulates your greatest strengths and the results that you’ve delivered, can stand in the way of you landing your dream job, even if you match every skill on the job description to the "T" and already have the necessary skills and experience they require.

Another thing that's concerning is that many job seekers I've spoken to in my coaching experience actually have the necessary skills, but fail to show it on their resumes.

There’s no point having specific technical skills and power skills, but not demonstrating them on your LinkedIn profile and in your resume. Your skills are your greatest asset, so failing to include them puts you at the back of the queue, while those who’ve worked hard to specialise and acquire the very skills you have will win the role you wanted, not because they are skilled more than you are, but simply because they know how to show it.

Now, to help you stand out from the crowd and impress employers and even prospective clients if you’re a freelancer, here are some free courses and certifications you can take to upskill in the areas listed above, whether you’re a software developer, UX designer, data analyst, or other professional in the industries included in Huntr’s report.

Oracle’s Oracle University is currently holding a “Race to Certification” which is a challenge anyone can participate in for free to upskill, gain badges and certificates, and have a chance to win some prizes and be featured on a leaderboard. Their free courses range from AI to cloud to data. Cloud courses and certificates include:
• and so much more.

Build and display your portfolio for free on platforms like:
• You can also learn on LinkedIn Learning’s courses (free with a trial or free to Premium members) such as Building a Portfolio With Adobe Portfolio

Product School has a range of free micro-certifications such as:

Microsoft has tons of hands-on training videos and step-by-step tutorials across all its apps, suitable for different roles including developers, start-up founders, consultants, and AI engineers. A few include:
• Explore Microsoft Teams (because to be honest, you’re still stuck using the same familiar features every day at work)
• Get Started With OneNote For Education (more niche, nuanced application)

How To Include These Skills/Certifications In Your Resume
• Build a portfolio of projects you’ve created while learning/past projects with results including any case studies, and include this link in your resume and LinkedIn profile.
• List only the relevant certifications, in reverse chronological order on your resume in a dedicated section near the education section.
• Where it makes sense and enables you to stand out due to your niche, include your certification by briefly mentioning it near the top of your resume, in the skills or professional summary sections.
• Don’t wait until you’ve finished; if you’re still working on completing your course, include it but write a note like “currently studying” or “due to complete by XYZ”.

It’s time to add some “oomph” to your resume and show employers exactly what your skills are worth.

Check out my recent article, 20 Courses & Certificates To Learn High-Income Skills In 2 Hours, for ways to learn and upskill even when you’re short on time.
summary: The article discusses the top skills gaps in the labor market, highlighting key competencies that are causing significant shortages and gaps within different markets and industries. The most critical gap within the software development field is cloud platforms, with only 0.07% of developer resumes mentioning this skill, despite 3.98% of job posts requiring it. Similarly, within data analytics, cloud platforms have emerged as the most significant skills shortage, hindering employers from tapping into high-skilled talent and reducing innovation. The article also reveals how to upskill in these core areas for free, and how to do so so to gain a competitive edge. It also provides a list of free courses and certifications that can help you stand out from crowd and impress prospective employers. The report by Huntr's (Oracle) University’s (Huntr) suggests that high-income skills can be acquired easily and inexpensively, meaning you don't even need a degree to acquire them.

scraped_sources.text:
Huntr Research
Job Search Trends Report Q2 2025
Huntr’s Q2 2025 Job Search Trends Report analyzes 461k applications, 285k job ads, 59k resumes and a 455-respondent survey to reveal slower hiring cycles, surging AI adoption, widening skills gaps and shifting pay + location expectations. Dive in for data-driven insights on where the market’s cooling and where candidates still hold the leverage.
Introduction
The second quarter of 2025 marked a decisive turning point in the post-pandemic labor market. Drawing on 461,000 tracked applications, 284,623 de-duplicated job listings, 59,000 resumes, and a 455-respondent survey.
Huntr’s Q2-2025 dataset shows the median time to first offer increasing by 22 percent to 68.5 days, even as the busiest 10 percent of candidates fired off 19 applications a week. LinkedIn still captured nearly four-fifths of job saves, yet Google Jobs delivered triple its callback rate, underscoring a widening gap between reach and effectiveness. Remote and hybrid roles now account for 83 percent of worker preferences, but more than half of postings omit any location guidance; evidence of mounting employer uncertainty.
Meanwhile AI has become a mainstream ally (93 percent of seekers deploy tools like ChatGPT to help with resumes/cover letters and more) yet seven in ten still reject one-way AI interviews, reaffirming the value of human connection. Layer in rising salary ambitions (43 percent now target $100k-plus), and the revelation that half of workers stay in disliked jobs for benefits or visas, and a picture emerges of a market simultaneously cooling, fragmenting, and reforming around new power centers of tech, transparency, and talent leverage.
Highlights of This Report
Your quick-scan overview of the standout findings from Q2 2025
From Search Insights
- Hiring Slowdown: Time to first offer has jumped 22% since April, now taking a median of 68.5 days.
- Post-Interview Delay: Candidates wait nearly twice as long after interviews (11 days) as they do to get them (6 days).
- Quality Versus Quantity of Applications: While the most common path to a job offer is a targeted search of 10-20 applications, a significant group of seekers must apply to over 100 jobs to achieve the same success.
From Job Search Sites Section
- LinkedIn Still Reigns: LinkedIn captured up to 80% of job saves in H1 2025, while Indeed’s share surged 65% since January.
- Response Rate Surprise: Google Jobs leads with a 9.3% response rate, nearly 3x higher than LinkedIn’s 3.3%.
- ATS Market Shift: Greenhouse grew its lead from 23% to 29%, while Lever fell sharply from 14% to 9% in H1 2025. AshbyHQ demonstrates consistent growth, rising from 11.15% to 14.56%, positioning itself as an up and coming ATS leader.
From Job Market Analysis
- C-Suite & Tech Leadership Dominate: CIOs top the charts at $286K, while principal engineers and architects now regularly earn over $200K.
- Advanced Degrees Pay Off: Doctorate holders earn 35% above average, with master's degrees close behind at a 29% premium.
- AI & Engineering Strategy Skills Command Premiums: Engineering leaders earn 112% more than average, with AI strategy and technical leadership close behind.
From Resume Insights
- Depth Over Length Wins: Interviewed resumes feature richer education blurbs, stronger LinkedIn presence, and fewer but more detailed work achievements.
- Less Is More: Successful resumes list fewer certifications and fewer skills, emphasizing focus over quantity.
- Experience Matters: Interviewed candidates show slightly longer tenures and more distinct roles, highlighting the value of sustained, varied experience.
Highlights for Job Search Survey Insights
- AI Acceptance Grows: 68% of job seekers say they’d accept a job offer without ever speaking to a human.
- Mental Health Matters: 1 in 3 workers have quit a job for mental health reasons, highlighting rising burnout.
- Free Labor Problem: Nearly half of job seekers report completing unpaid projects during the interview process.
How We Gathered This Data
Data for Job Search Insights
We mined the anonymized activity logs from Huntr’s Job Tracker—every application, stage change, and offer recorded by users between April 2025 and June 2025. Covering 461k job entries created by 17,733 job seekers, giving us precise timestamps to measure time-to-interview, offer velocity, and weekly application cadence.
Data for Job Search Sites
Whenever a user saves a posting, Huntr captures the source URL. For Q2 2025, that produced ≈364k saved jobs, which we grouped by domain to rank boards like LinkedIn or Indeed, and by ATS domains to see which systems dominate. Response rates come from users moving a saved job into “Interview” or beyond, an on-platform action that signals an employer callback. Our metrics in this section key off the root domain of each saved posting (e.g., linkedin.com, indeed.com). This approach cleanly captures stand-alone boards but under-represents applicant-tracking systems (ATSs) that embed their pages inside a company’s own URL; for example, a Greenhouse job served at careers.acme.com/… is attributed to Acme rather than to Greenhouse. As a result, site-level popularity and callback rates favor public boards and may understate the reach of ATS platforms embedded within corporate domains.
Data for Job Market Analysis
To avoid double-counting identical roles posted across multiple boards or refresh dates, we deduplicated every listing at the job-title × company level. In Q2 2025, that yielded 284,623 unique job-company combinations from the original 461,000 saved jobs. All salary, degree, skill-premium, and location analyses start with this de-duped set, then narrow further. By basing every metric on one record per employer role, we ensure our pay and demand numbers reflect distinct openings rather than repeated advertisements.
Data for Resume Insights
From 59,071 resumes created in Q2 (64.3% job-tailored, 35.7% base) by 15,405 unique authors, we extracted structured fields; sections used, bullet counts, character lengths, and social links. To link resume quality with outcomes, we focused on the 37,976 job-tailored files tied to tracked applications, comparing the 1,187 that led to a self-reported interview to the rest.
Data for Job Search Survey Insights
Finally, we fielded a 28-question web survey in June 2025, collecting 455 complete responses across industries, seniorities, and geographies. The survey supplements platform telemetry with diversity, mental health, AI sentiment, layoffs, salary expectations, and more.
Dataset Composition
Before diving into the findings, it’s important to understand who and what sits behind the numbers. Most headline metrics in this report focus on Q2 2025 (April 1 – June 31). Still, any quarter-over-quarter trendlines or “growth since last quarter” call-outs extend back to Jan 1, 2025 to give a consistent six-month comparison window. Data streams include platform telemetry (jobs, applications, resumes), parsed job ads, and a 455-respondent survey.
Geographic Representation
Among the Q2 2025 records with location data, the platform exhibits a heavily North American-centric distribution. North America dominates with 69.2% of job postings and 65.5% of resume creations, with the United States alone accounting for 56.6% of located job postings and 53.5% of located resumes. Europe maintains a consistent second position, representing approximately 20% of both jobs and resumes across key markets including the UK, Germany, France, and Italy.
Implication: Hiring and pay insights are most reliable for the U.S. and Canadian markets and may not generalize globally.
Industry and Job-Function Mix
The Q2 2025 job market data reveals a heavily tech-dominated landscape, with Internet Software & Services representing 22.4% of all postings, followed by Professional Services (10.9%) and Financial Services (3.5%). The job role distribution reflects this tech concentration: Engineering/Development positions comprise 27.4% of all listings, with Software Engineers, DevOps Engineers, and Front-End Developers among the most sought-after roles. Design positions form another significant category at 13.3%, led by Product Designers (1.9% of all jobs) and UX Designers. Data-related roles represent 12.6% of postings, highlighting the continued importance of analytics capabilities across industries.
Implication: Trend signals are strongest for tech and industrial hiring; other fields should view the data as directional only.
Experience-Level Distribution in Resumes
- Entry-level: 39.2%
- Senior-level: 32.4%
- Mid-level: 21.6%
- Unspecified: 6.8%
Implication: Behaviors such as resume length or section usage may tilt toward early-career norms.
Salary-Data Coverage
Only 29.3% of jobs include salary information, but those that do reveal competitive compensation with median annual salaries ranging from $100,624 to $143,750.
Company-Size Representation
Among jobs with known company sizes, enterprise companies (1000+ employees) dominate with 34.4% of postings. Medium-sized companies (51-250 employees) represent the second-largest segment at 20.7%, followed by small businesses (11-50 employees) at 18.6%.
Data Integrity and Disclaimer
All insights in this report are based on anonymized user activity and self-reported survey data from Huntr’s platform. Metrics and examples involving employers or platforms reflect aggregate user trends and are not endorsements or critiques of those companies. While care has been taken to ensure data accuracy, all findings should be interpreted as indicative, not definitive.
Job Search Insights
Time to First Offer
Hiring Takes Longer: Time to First Offer Up 22% Since April
The hiring process is becoming increasingly protracted, with the median time from search initiation to first offer extending from 56 days in April to 68.5 days by June.
This represents a concerning 22% increase over just three months, suggesting that organizations are taking substantially longer to move candidates through their recruitment pipelines.
The steady month-over-month deterioration, jumping 11 days from April to May, then another 1.5 days into June, indicates a systematic slowdown rather than seasonal fluctuation.
This trend could reflect tighter hiring standards, more complex approval processes, or increased candidate evaluation requirements as companies become more selective in their recruitment decisions.
Individual Job Timeline
Interview to Offer Takes Nearly Twice as Long as Application to Interview
The job search process reveals a telling pattern in timing expectations. Once an application is submitted, candidates typically wait six days before hearing back for an interview opportunity.
However, the real test of patience comes afterward, the journey from completing interviews to receiving an offer stretches nearly twice as long at eleven days.
This extended decision-making period reflects the complexity of hiring processes, where companies often need time to evaluate multiple candidates, conduct internal discussions, and navigate approval workflows.
For job seekers, understanding these timelines can help manage expectations and reduce anxiety during what is often the most uncertain phase of career transitions.
The nearly two-week wait after interviewing represents a critical period where persistence and patience become essential virtues in the pursuit of new opportunities.
Time to First Interview
Half of Job Seekers Receive their First Interview in 22 days or Less
The job interview process reveals a surprising reality for candidates seeking employment opportunities.
While half of all applicants receive their first interview invitation within just over three weeks, the experience becomes increasingly challenging for those who must wait longer.
Candidates in the 75th percentile face nearly two months of waiting before hearing back from potential employers.
The situation becomes particularly difficult for the unlucky few in the 90th percentile, who endure almost four months before receiving their first interview opportunity.
This disparity highlights the unpredictable nature of the hiring process, where timing and circumstances can dramatically impact a candidate's journey from application to that crucial first conversation with a prospective employer.
Number of Applications Per Week
Application Volume Varies Dramatically Across Job Seekers
While half of all job seekers submit 4 or fewer applications per week, the most active quarter of applicants are submitting more than twice that number at 9 applications weekly.
The gap becomes even more pronounced at the highest activity levels, where the top 10% of job seekers are pushing out 19 applications per week - nearly five times the median rate.
This distribution suggests two distinct job search strategies in the market. The majority of job seekers appear to be taking a more selective, targeted approach with fewer applications, while a smaller segment is pursuing a high-volume strategy.
The dramatic increase from the 75th to 90th percentile indicates that the most aggressive job seekers are significantly outpacing their peers, potentially creating competitive pressure in the job market as these high-volume applicants compete for the same positions.
Applications Created Before Offer Received
How Many Applications Job Seekers Need Before Getting an Offer
From Targeted Search to High-Volume Strategy
Our analysis of job seeker activity from Q2 2025 reveals a fascinating distribution in the number of applications required to secure a job offer.
The data indicates that the most common path to success involves submitting between 10 and 20 applications, which accounted for the largest single cohort of users at 20.8%. However, the distribution is not a simple bell curve.
A significant and contrasting trend emerges at the higher end, with 14.3% of users submitting over 100 applications before receiving an offer.
This suggests that while a targeted, efficient search yields results for many, a substantial portion of the job-seeking population must engage in a high-volume, persistent strategy to achieve their goal.
Job Search Sites
With nearly 460k jobs saved in Q2 through our job tracker, we’ve gained unique, ground-level insight into how different job search sites are actually serving job seekers. Since our data is self-reported, you can consider the metrics below as lower bounds; not every user returns to update their progress, like whether they landed an interview.
Most Popular Job Sites
LinkedIn Dominates Job Market with Nearly 80% Share, While Indeed Shows Strong Growth
LinkedIn continues to maintain its overwhelming dominance in the job market, consistently capturing between 77% and 80% of all job saves across the first half of 2025.
The professional networking platform's market share remains remarkably stable month-over-month, demonstrating its entrenched position as the go-to destination for job seekers.
Meanwhile, Indeed emerges as the clear second player, showing impressive growth momentum by expanding its market share from 6.34% in January to 10.48% in June, a 65% increase that suggests it's successfully competing for LinkedIn's users.
In contrast, traditional job boards like Dice experienced significant decline, dropping from 4.13% to just 1.53% over the same period. The remaining players, including ZipRecruiter, Glassdoor, Welcome to the Jungle, and Wellfound, collectively hold single-digit market shares, while other smaller sites maintain a steady 5-6% of the market.
This data reveals a increasingly concentrated job search landscape where LinkedIn's professional network effect continues to drive user preference, though Indeed's rapid growth indicates there's still room for competition in the evolving digital recruitment space.
Job Search Sites Responsiveness
Google Jobs Delivers Best Response Rates Among Major Platforms
Certain job sites have higher response rates than others based on user self-reporting. We consider a 'response' as a user moving the job to the interview stage or further in their job search process. That means, if you applied for a job on a particular site, you've heard back from that site at a certain rate.
When it comes to getting responses from job applications, not all popular platforms are created equal. Google Jobs stands out as the clear winner with an impressive 9.3% response rate, nearly three times higher than LinkedIn's 3.3% rate despite LinkedIn processing over 114,000 applications.
The most striking finding reveals a disconnect between platform popularity and effectiveness - while LinkedIn dominates application volume, specialized platforms like Glassdoor.com (7.3%) and Wellfound (6.4%) significantly outperform the networking giant in converting applications to interviews.
At the bottom end, tech-focused platforms struggle with Dice.com managing only 1.4% of applications receiving responses, suggesting that platform reputation doesn't always translate to hiring manager engagement.
Top Companies Responsiveness
Teksystems and Cisco Lead the Pack in Lightning-Fast Interview Scheduling
Teksystems emerges as the speed champion, connecting with candidates in just 6.5 days on average, closely followed by Cisco at 6.7 days.
These tech staffing and networking giants demonstrate that rapid response times are achievable even at scale. On the opposite end of the spectrum, Pinterest takes over five weeks (37.5 days) to schedule interviews, suggesting a more deliberate—or perhaps overwhelmed—approach to candidate evaluation.
Capital One and Canonical also lag significantly behind, requiring over a month each. The middle ground tells an interesting story too: Amazon, despite handling the highest volume of interviews, maintains a respectable 22-day turnaround.
Meanwhile, Google keeps pace with industry leaders at just over 9 days, proving that even tech titans can move swiftly when motivated. These timing differences likely reflect varying company cultures, internal processes, and strategic priorities around talent acquisition speed versus thoroughness.
Popular Applicant Tracking Systems
Greenhouse Dominates ATS Market
The applicant tracking systems landscape shows clear market leaders and notable shifts in the first half of 2025. Greenhouse.io commands the largest market share, growing from 23.27% in January to 29.26% in June, solidifying its position as the dominant platform for job postings.
MyWorkdayJobs maintains the second-largest share but shows some decline from 17.63% to 15.96% over the period. Meanwhile, AshbyHQ demonstrates consistent growth, rising from 11.15% to 14.56%, positioning itself as a strong third player.
The most significant decline comes from Lever, which dropped dramatically from 14.38% in January to just 8.99% by June, suggesting potential challenges in retaining market position.
The remaining smaller ATS platforms collectively represent about 20-23% of the market, indicating a fragmented landscape where the top three systems increasingly dominate job posting distribution.
This data suggests companies are consolidating around fewer, more established platforms, with Greenhouse.io emerging as the clear winner in the competitive ATS space.
* Go here for more information on how this data was calculated
Resume Insights
Resume Success Factors
A successful resume is one that led to an interview, as recorded by users in our job tracker system. Although the true number of interviews is likely underreported, since many users do not consistently update their interview status, the trends observed still offer meaningful insight into what makes a resume effective.
Our findings indicate that the strength of a successful resume lies not in its length but in the depth of its content in key areas. Candidates who secured interviews typically included more detailed educational histories, had more years of experience, and were more likely to include a LinkedIn profile. In contrast, those who were not interviewed tended to emphasize a greater number of skills and certifications. This contrast suggests that employers prioritize strong professional storytelling over exhaustive lists of competencies, an approach that can significantly influence the likelihood of landing an interview.
Tailoring Resume to Job Descriptions
Tailored Resumes Drive 2.1x Higher Interview Conversion Rates
Our analysis of self-reported job application data reveals a significant performance gap between tailored and generic resume approaches. Users who customized their resumes for specific positions achieved a 5.75% conversion rate from application to interview or offer stage, compared to just 2.68% for those who did not have a tailored resume, representing a 115% improvement in success rates.
Based on over 1.39 million applications, since Q4 2024, the data shows tailored resumes generate approximately 6 interview opportunities per 100 applications, compared to fewer than 3 for generic submissions. Since these figures rely on user-reported outcomes for interviews, offers, and hiring decisions, they likely represent conservative floor estimates of the true impact. The findings underscore the critical importance of resume customization in today's competitive job market, where personalized applications demonstrably outperform generic submissions in advancing through hiring processes.
Education Section
Detailed Education Descriptions Give Interview Edge
Resumes that led to interviews have slightly longer education descriptions (100 characters) compared to those who did not (86 characters), suggesting that providing more detailed educational background helps secure interviews.
Certification Section
More Certifications Don't Equal More Interviews
Resumes that did not lead to interviews had more certifications on average (1.41 vs 1.32), indicating that simply accumulating credentials doesn't guarantee interview opportunities.
Skills Section
Comprehensive Skills Lists Show Modest Interview Advantage
Interviewed candidates listed slightly more skills (29.9 vs 29.3), though the small difference suggests that having a comprehensive skills section provides only modest advantages.
Achievements
Quality Over Quantity Wins in Achievement Writing
Interviewed candidates wrote fewer but more detailed achievements (4.35 per job at 164 characters each) compared to those not interviewed (4.88 per job at 161 characters each), demonstrating that quality trumps quantity in achievement descriptions.
Work Experience
Career Progression and Experience Drive Interview Success
Interviewed candidates had both more roles (4.76 vs 4.52) and more total experience (10.5 vs 9.5 years), showing that career progression and tenure both contribute to interview success.
Resume Length by Page Count
Busting the One-Page Resume Myth: A Data-Driven Answer
For decades, job seekers have been told to adhere to the strict "one-page rule" for resumes. However, a comprehensive analysis of 76,401 resumes shows that two-page resumes actually have the highest success rate, securing interviews 3.69% of the time. While this is only slightly higher than the 3.36% rate for one-page resumes, the key takeaway is that job seekers should not feel shackled by the one-page myth.
If you can effectively showcase your accomplishments on a single page, that's excellent. However, our data suggests it's perfectly acceptable to use a second or even third page (which still sees a strong 3.22% interview rate) if your experience and achievements warrant the space. For more details on our methodology and how we define a resume receiving an interview, please refer to the "Data for Resume Insights" section.
Slightly Longer Resumes Get More Interview Attention
Interviewed candidates had slightly longer resumes (1.71 vs 1.64 pages), suggesting that providing comprehensive information without being overly verbose is beneficial.
Summary
Concise Summaries Outperform Lengthy Ones
While interviewed candidates were more likely to include summaries (94.0% vs 90.2%), they wrote shorter ones (524 vs 568 characters), indicating that concise, focused summaries outperform lengthy ones.
Projects
Brief Project Descriptions Work Better Than Detailed Ones
Interviewed candidates wrote much shorter project descriptions (45 vs 103 characters), demonstrating that brevity and focus are more effective than detailed explanations.
Social Links
Platform-specific social links and interview success
Candidates who were interviewed had significantly higher LinkedIn presence (69.4%) compared to those who weren't (61.0%), but surprisingly had lower GitHub presence, suggesting that professional networking trumps code portfolios for getting initial interviews.
Contact Info
Email Beats Phone for Professional Contact
Both groups had excellent contact information presence, with interviewed candidates having slightly higher email presence (98.9% vs 98.3%) but lower phone presence (91.6% vs 92.5%), suggesting email is more critical than phone for professional communication.
Resume Sections and Length
Resume Section Popularity Overall
LinkedIn Creates 50% Divide Between Traditional and Modern Resume Approaches
Contact information dominates resume construction, with email addresses appearing in over 93% of base resumes, followed closely by work experience at 89% and education at nearly 89%.
Phone numbers maintain strong adoption at 86%, while skills sections appear in 84% of resumes. Professional summaries show solid usage at 78%, creating a clear tier of essential resume components.
A significant drop occurs with LinkedIn profiles at 51%, suggesting a divide between traditional and modern networking approaches. Specialized sections like certifications (40%), projects (27%), and volunteer experience (13%) reveal more selective usage patterns.
Technical elements such as GitHub profiles (11%) and custom links (9%) remain niche, while location information appears in fewer than 9% of resumes.
Social media presence beyond LinkedIn proves minimal, with Twitter and Dribbble representing less than 1% of resume inclusion.
Resume Section Popularity by Job Category
Essential Resume Sections Drive Universal Adoption
Essential resume sections reveal clear patterns across industries, with contact information and core credentials forming the universal foundation.
Email addresses appear on nearly every resume (96-99%), while education and work experience maintain similarly high adoption rates above 88%. Industry-specific variations emerge in specialized areas: Information Security professionals lead in certifications at 68%, Creative fields show highest portfolio link usage at 57%, and technical roles demonstrate stronger GitHub presence.
Professional networking through LinkedIn maintains moderate adoption between 30-67%, while platform-specific profiles like Twitter and Dribbble remain minimal below 1.4%, suggesting professionals strategically curate their digital presence based on career relevance rather than comprehensive social media representation.
Number and Length of Work Experience By Target Seniority
Senior Professionals Accumulate 14 Years of Experience Across Just 5 Positions
Resume experience patterns reveal distinct career progression stages across seniority levels.
Entry-level professionals typically accumulate 2 years of experience through 3 different positions, suggesting frequent job changes early in their careers as they explore opportunities and build foundational skills.
Mid-level professionals demonstrate more stability with 6 years of experience across 4 positions, indicating longer tenure per role as they develop specialized expertise.
Senior professionals show the most dramatic jump to 14 years of experience with 5 positions, reflecting sustained career development and strategic role transitions.
The progression shows a clear pattern where years of experience grow exponentially while the number of positions increases more gradually, indicating that career advancement involves both breadth of exposure and depth of experience within each role.
Number and Length of Achievements By Target Seniority
Senior Professionals Write 10% Longer Achievement Descriptions Despite Same Quantity
Resume achievement patterns reveal interesting progression trends across experience levels.
Entry-level professionals maintain a median of 3 achievements per work experience, with an average character length of 111.8 per achievement. Mid-level professionals show a slight increase to 4 achievements while maintaining similar descriptive detail at 118 characters.
Senior professionals also average 4 achievements per role, but demonstrate more comprehensive descriptions at 123.5 characters each. The most notable pattern emerges in the consistency of achievement quantity between mid-level and senior roles, suggesting that professionals plateau at around 4 key accomplishments per position, while the increasing character length indicates more detailed and complex responsibility descriptions as seniority advances.
Resume Page Count by Experience
Senior Professionals Favor Longer Resumes While Entry-Level Workers Keep It Brief
The resume length preferences vary dramatically across experience levels, with a clear inverse relationship between career stage and single-page resumes.
Entry-level professionals overwhelmingly prefer concise formats, with 31.1% using one page and 60.3% sticking to two pages. Mid-level professionals show an even stronger preference for two-page resumes at 65.7%, while only 18.5% opt for single pages.
Senior professionals demonstrate the most diverse approach to resume length, with just 10.7% using one page and nearly a third (28.1%) extending to three pages.
This pattern suggests that as professionals accumulate experience, achievements, and responsibilities, they require more space to effectively communicate their value proposition.
The shift toward longer formats among senior professionals likely reflects the need to showcase extensive project portfolios, leadership experience, and technical expertise that can't be adequately captured in brief formats.
Number of Skills
Median number of skills listed in resumes is 9
This analysis examines the number of skills listed on resumes across our platform during Q2 2025. The data represents unique users who had at least one skill listed on their resume, with each user counted only once (using their most complete resume if multiple versions existed).
The metrics were calculated by analyzing the length of the skills section for each resume, capturing the 25th percentile, median, and 75th percentile values to understand the typical distribution.
It reveals a clear distribution pattern, with most professionals clustering around 9 skills on their resumes. At the lower end, 25% of job seekers list 7 or fewer skills, while the top quartile showcases 12 or more competencies.
Work Tenure and Experience Years
Work Tenure by Job Title
Your Frontend Developer Has Packed More Jobs Into Five Years Than Your Office Manager Has in a Decade
General managers emerge as the most tenured professionals, maintaining an average tenure of 6.8 years in their roles.
Traditional management and consulting positions dominate the upper echelon of job stability, with managers, consultants, and senior consultants all exceeding six years of tenure.
This pattern suggests that leadership roles and advisory positions offer greater career satisfaction and stability compared to more technical or specialized functions.
The engineering landscape reveals an interesting hierarchy of tenure, where senior software engineers maintain longer tenures (5.2 years) than their non-senior counterparts (4.3 years), and both significantly outlast the newer development specializations.
Full stack developers (3.7 years) and frontend developers (3.5 years) show notably shorter tenure periods, possibly reflecting the rapidly evolving nature of these specialized roles and the high demand for their skills in the job market.
Perhaps most striking is the contrast between traditional business functions and emerging technology roles. While customer service representatives maintain solid 4.5-year tenures, newer disciplines like data science (3.2 years) and data engineering (3.1 years) show considerably shorter job retention.
This divergence highlights how established business functions offer more predictable career paths, while cutting-edge technology roles may encourage more frequent movement between organizations as professionals seek to maximize their rapidly appreciating skill sets.
Total Experience Years by Target Title
Technical Leadership Demands Significant Experience Investment
This chart presents the median years of total work experience found in resumes targeting specific job titles, based on data collected from tens of thousands of job seeker resumes in Q2 2025.
The analysis examines each resume's combined work history, calculating the total years of experience across all positions and grouping by the job title the resume is targeting. For users with multiple resumes targeting the same role, only their maximum experience value was counted to avoid duplication.
The path to executive leadership is longer than most professionals expect. Chief Operating Officers have spent nearly 22 years honing their skills before reaching the pinnacle of operational leadership, while General Managers and Executive Directors aren't far behind with over 20 years of experience each.
This isn't just about climbing the corporate ladder; it's about accumulating the deep institutional knowledge, crisis management skills, and strategic thinking that only comes from decades in the trenches.
Technical leadership roles demand an equally impressive commitment, with Directors of Engineering requiring nearly 18 years to master both the technical complexity and people management skills their roles demand.
Even specialized positions like Solution Architects need almost 15 years to develop the systems thinking and client-facing expertise that makes them indispensable. Perhaps most telling is the clear progression pathway that emerges: professionals typically need over a decade to reach senior management roles, nearly two decades for director-level positions, and more than 20 years to qualify for C-suite responsibilities.
This timeline reflects the reality that true leadership expertise cannot be rushed—it requires the patient accumulation of experience across multiple business cycles, technological shifts, and organizational challenges.

Most Popular Skills by Target Title Category
The Modern Professional Landscape: Where Technology Meets Human Expertise
Across every professional discipline, a fascinating transformation is reshaping the modern workplace where technical proficiency has become as essential as domain expertise. From Python's dominance in technical fields to Excel's universal presence in business operations, professionals must navigate an increasingly sophisticated technological ecosystem while maintaining the human skills that drive organizational success. The data reveals a striking pattern: regardless of whether someone works in creative design, financial analysis, or customer service, modern roles demand fluency in multiple software platforms, analytical thinking, and collaborative tools. This convergence suggests we're witnessing the emergence of a new type of professional, one who seamlessly blends technical competency with specialized knowledge, using technology not as a replacement for human judgment but as an amplifier of human capability. The most successful careers now belong to those who can master both the digital tools of their trade and the timeless skills of communication, problem-solving, and strategic thinking that no algorithm can replicate.
Software & IT - Python: The Programming Powerhouse
Software and IT professionals live in a world where adaptability and technical mastery reign supreme. Python emerges as the undisputed champion, appearing on nearly nine out of ten resumes in this field. The landscape reveals a fascinating blend of foundational programming languages, version control systems, and cloud technologies. From JavaScript's web dominance to Docker's containerization revolution, these professionals must navigate an ecosystem where traditional databases meet modern DevOps practices. The skill set reflects an industry in constant evolution, where yesterday's cutting-edge framework becomes today's standard toolkit.
Data Science - Python: The Data Scientist's Swiss Army Knife
Data science represents the perfect marriage of statistical rigor and programming prowess, with Python leading an impressive parade of analytical tools. The field demands fluency in both the theoretical and practical, where SQL databases meet machine learning libraries, and business intelligence platforms transform raw numbers into strategic insights. Visualization tools like Tableau and specialized Python libraries create a comprehensive toolkit for extracting meaning from chaos. This profession requires individuals who can seamlessly transition from statistical analysis to data storytelling, making complex insights accessible to decision-makers.
Creative & Design - Figma: Designing the Digital Experience
Creative and design professionals operate at the intersection of aesthetics and functionality, where Figma has revolutionized collaborative design workflows. The modern design landscape encompasses everything from user research methodologies to prototyping tools, reflecting an industry that has moved far beyond traditional graphic design. Adobe's Creative Suite maintains its relevance alongside newer platforms, while UX/UI principles dominate the skill requirements. Designers must be strategic thinkers, user advocates, and technical implementers all rolled into one, crafting experiences that delight users while meeting business objectives.
Product Management - Jira: Orchestrating Product Success
Product management has evolved into a discipline that demands equal parts technical acumen and strategic vision, with Jira serving as the central nervous system for product development. These professionals must speak multiple languages fluently: the technical dialect of SQL and Python, the design vocabulary of Figma, and the analytical tongue of Tableau. The role requires individuals who can bridge disparate teams, translate business requirements into technical specifications, and guide products from conception to market success. It's a profession where data-driven decision making meets human intuition.
Marketing and Advertising - Google Analytics: Measuring What Matters
Marketing and advertising professionals navigate an increasingly complex digital landscape where data analytics drives creative strategy. The field has transformed from intuition-based campaigns to precision-targeted, measurable initiatives. Modern marketers must master both the creative tools that bring campaigns to life and the analytical platforms that prove their worth. From content creation software to customer relationship management systems, success requires a blend of artistic vision and scientific measurement. The most effective professionals understand that great marketing today is equal parts art and science.
Sales & Business Development - Salesforce: The Revenue Engine
Sales and business development professionals operate in an environment where relationship building meets technological sophistication. Customer relationship management systems have become the backbone of modern sales operations, transforming how professionals track prospects, manage pipelines, and nurture client relationships. The field demands a unique combination of interpersonal excellence and technical proficiency, where traditional sales skills like negotiation and communication are enhanced by data analytics and automation tools. Success requires individuals who can leverage technology to scale human connections.
Information Security - Python: Defending the Digital Frontier
Information security professionals stand as the guardians of our digital infrastructure, wielding Python as their primary weapon against increasingly sophisticated threats. The cybersecurity landscape demands deep technical knowledge spanning multiple operating systems, network protocols, and security frameworks. These professionals must think like both architects and attackers, understanding system vulnerabilities while implementing robust defenses. From network analysis tools to compliance frameworks, the field requires individuals who can balance proactive security measures with incident response capabilities, protecting organizations in an ever-evolving threat landscape.
Administrative & Clerical - Microsoft Office: The Foundation of Business Operations
Administrative and clerical professionals serve as the operational backbone of organizations, with Microsoft Office skills forming the cornerstone of modern business efficiency. These roles have evolved far beyond traditional secretarial duties, now encompassing project coordination, data management, and digital communication facilitation. The modern administrative professional must navigate multiple software platforms while maintaining the human touch that keeps organizations running smoothly. Success in this field requires individuals who can seamlessly blend technical proficiency with exceptional organizational and interpersonal skills.
Customer Support & Service - Microsoft Office: Connecting Customers and Solutions
Customer support and service professionals operate at the critical intersection where technology meets human need, requiring mastery of both software platforms and emotional intelligence. The field has transformed from simple problem-solving to comprehensive customer experience management. Modern support professionals must navigate complex technical systems while maintaining empathy and patience with frustrated customers. The role demands individuals who can quickly adapt to new technologies while never losing sight of the human element that defines exceptional service.
Finance & Accounting - Excel: The Financial Swiss Army Knife
Finance and accounting professionals wield Excel as their primary analytical weapon, transforming raw numbers into strategic business insights. The modern financial landscape requires fluency in multiple data analysis platforms, enterprise software systems, and specialized financial modeling tools. These professionals must balance technical precision with strategic thinking, ensuring accuracy while providing forward-looking analysis that guides business decisions. Success requires individuals who can navigate complex regulatory requirements while leveraging technology to automate routine tasks and focus on value-added analysis.

Salaries By Role
Top paying Job Titles
The C-Suite Commands the Highest Compensation
Chief Information Officers lead the pack with a commanding median salary of $286,250, reflecting the critical importance of technology leadership in today's business landscape.
The executive tier dominates the top rankings, with VPs earning $247,500 and General Counsel at $247,095, underscoring how strategic decision-making roles continue to attract premium compensation.
What's particularly striking is the emergence of technical architecture and engineering leadership positions among the highest-paid roles; Principal Software Engineers ($208,425), Architecture ($208,050), and Engineering ($205,250) all crack the $200,000 threshold, signaling a market that increasingly values technical expertise at the senior level.
The salary progression reveals fascinating patterns about organizational priorities.

Salaries By Education Requirements
Top Paying Degrees
Advanced Degrees Drive Tech Salaries: Doctorate Holders Lead with $165K Average
Higher education clearly pays off in the tech industry, with doctorate holders commanding the highest average salaries at $165,422, followed closely by master's degree professionals at $157,894. The salary progression follows an intuitive pattern, showing a significant jump from associate degrees ($72,283) to bachelor's degrees ($138,530) - a leap of over $66,000 that represents the traditional college premium. Interestingly, high school graduates ($78,717) actually out-earn those with associate degrees by about $6,400, suggesting that some high-paying technical roles may value experience and skills over formal credentials. When compared to the industry average of $122,569, bachelor's degree holders sit right at the threshold with a modest 13% premium, while advanced degrees show increasingly attractive returns - master's holders enjoy a 29% salary boost, and doctorate professionals command a 35% premium above the industry baseline.

Social Workers and Teachers Face 25-42% Salary Penalties Despite Critical Societal Contributions

International relations professionals earn just $70,000 annually; 42% below the market average; while social workers, who tackle our most pressing societal challenges, barely reach $73,000. This compensation gap highlights a troubling misalignment between social value and financial reward, where those dedicated to public service, education, and creative expression face systematic undervaluation in the marketplace. The pattern suggests that while technical skills command premium wages, the human-centered professions that form the backbone of civil society continue to be financially underappreciated.

Salaries by Company Size
Salary By Company Size
How Company Size Determines Your Salary
The tech industry's compensation landscape reveals a reality: your paycheck might depend as much on your company's size as your skills. At startups with fewer than 10 employees, the median salary hovers around $119,000 – a respectable figure that reflects the scrappy, all-hands-on-deck nature of early-stage ventures.
As companies grow to 11-50 employees, that number nudges up to $122,500, while mid-sized firms with 51-250 workers offer $125,000. Interestingly, companies in the 251-1000 range maintain that same $125,000 median, suggesting a plateau in the middle market.
But here's where things get interesting: once you hit the big leagues – companies with 1,000+ employees – the median salary jumps to $130,000.
That $11,000 difference between the smallest and largest companies represents more than just a bigger paycheck; it's a window into how established tech giants can afford to pay premium wages while smaller companies often compensate with equity, flexibility, and the promise of rapid growth.

Fields of Study Growing in Demand
This analysis explores shifting requirements for fields of study in tech job postings, comparing Q1 2025 to Q2 2025. The data highlights the relative growth percentage for fields that saw a meaningful percentage point increase (≥0.25%) in job listings referencing these qualifications. Percentage point (pp) change is calculated by subtracting the Q1 percentage from the Q2 percentage. For instance, let's say Marketing was mentioned in 1.27% of job postings in Q1 2025 and increased to 1.84% in Q2 2025, resulting in a 0.57 percentage point rise. The relative change (44.88%) indicates how significant this increase is compared to the original value (0.57 ÷ 1.27 = 44.88%).

Traditional business disciplines dominated the growth rankings, with Business, Business Administration, and Accounting all posting gains above 20%. Marketing and Economics showed healthy increases of 17.93% and 14.19% respectively.
Notably, only two technical fields appeared among the top growth areas—Cybersecurity with a modest 7.69% increase and Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) with minimal growth of 1.96%.
This shift toward business-oriented fields suggests employers are prioritizing commercial and communication skills over pure technical expertise, marking a potential pivot in hiring strategies across industries.
Fields of Study with Declining Demand
This visualization highlights fields of study that saw significant drops in demand across tech job listings, comparing Q1 2025 to Q2 2025. The chart presents relative decline percentages for fields with decreases of at least 0.25 percentage points in job requirements. For example, if "X Field of Study" appeared in 10% of job listings in Q1 2025 but dropped to 5% in Q2 2025, reflecting a -5 percentage point change. The relative decline of -50% is calculated by dividing this change by the original percentage (-5 ÷ 10 = -50%), indicating how substantial the decrease is relative to its initial value.

Industry
Industry Concentration in Our Top Cities
How we came up with our rankings
We introduce a novel approach to visualizing industry concentration across North American cities. Rather than relying solely on absolute job numbers, which can be skewed toward larger metropolitan areas, we've calculated the percentage of each city's total job listings that belong to specific industries.
The heatmap visualization ranks cities by their industry concentration, showing the top five locations where each industry represents the highest proportion of local job opportunities. This approach addresses several limitations in traditional job market data. First, it compensates for sampling biases in our user base, which may over-represent certain regions. Second, it normalizes for population differences, allowing smaller cities with strong industry presence to appear alongside major metropolitan areas.
It's important to note that high concentration doesn't necessarily indicate the highest number of available positions; rather, it signals where specific industries play a particularly significant role in the local economy.
Silicon Valley's Grip Tightens: San Francisco, Seattle, and San Jose Command Top Three in Internet Software Jobs
The job market data reveals distinct geographic clustering patterns across North America's major tech and business hubs.
San Francisco claims the top spot in Internet Software, followed by Seattle in second and San Jose in third, highlighting Silicon Valley's continued supremacy in tech innovation. Interestingly, Winnipeg ranks first in Professional Services, outpacing traditional business centers like Washington DC (second) and Charlotte (third).
Financial services show a more distributed pattern, with Toronto leading the rankings but Charlotte, New York, and Dallas all securing positions in the top four. The data also reveals specialized industry clusters: Charlotte's first-place ranking in banking, Boston's leadership positions in both healthcare providers and pharmaceuticals, and San Jose's top rankings in both semiconductors and communications equipment.
These patterns suggest that while certain cities have established themselves as clear industry leaders, the job market shows both expected concentrations (tech cities dominating software rankings, finance in traditional hubs) and some surprising regional strengths, particularly in Canadian markets and emerging US business centers.
The concentration is so strong in some sectors that the same cities appear repeatedly in top rankings - San Jose holds first place in three different tech-related industries, while Boston leads in two healthcare sectors.
Location Requirements
Location Requirements by Company Size
Work Location Transparency Declines as Company Size Grows
The relationship between company size and work arrangement transparency reveals a striking pattern across job postings.
Small companies with 1-10 employees demonstrate the highest commitment to remote work at 31.82%, yet this percentage steadily decreases as organizations grow larger, dropping to just 15.50% for companies with over 1,000 employees.
What's most remarkable is the inverse trend in unspecified work arrangements, while smaller companies leave 39.51% of their postings ambiguous about location requirements, this figure climbs dramatically to 52.53% for the largest enterprises.
This suggests that major corporations are increasingly reluctant to commit to specific work arrangements in their job advertisements, perhaps maintaining flexibility for case-by-case negotiations.
Meanwhile, hybrid and onsite arrangements remain relatively stable across all company sizes, hovering between 12-16% each, indicating these models have found consistent adoption regardless of organizational scale.
The findings challenge assumptions about large companies being more structured in their communications, instead revealing that smaller organizations provide clearer expectations about where work will actually happen.
Location Requirements by Job Category
Remote Work Dominates While Hybrid Struggles to Find Footing
The modern job market shows a clear preference for remote work opportunities, with most professional categories offering 13-32% of positions as fully remote, led by Customer Support & Service at 32.04% and Writing & Editing at 30.67%.
However, hybrid arrangements consistently lag behind across all fields, rarely exceeding 19% in any category except Legal (19.09%), suggesting organizations favor decisive remote or onsite policies over flexible splitting arrangements.
Interestingly, Science & Research bucks the remote trend entirely, showing the lowest remote adoption at just 9.86% while maintaining the highest onsite requirements at 19.97%, demonstrating that research-intensive roles requiring specialized equipment and collaborative lab work continue to favor in-person environments.
Monthly Trends in Location Requirements
Job Posting Ambiguity Reaches New High: 54% of Listings Fail to Mention Work Location by June 2025
Job posting transparency has reached a troubling low point, with over half of all listings now failing to specify location requirements, a trend that has accelerated dramatically throughout early 2025. This growing ambiguity represents a fundamental shift in how employers communicate workplace expectations, leaving job seekers to guess whether positions are remote, hybrid, or onsite.
While remote opportunities continue their gradual decline and hybrid arrangements hold steady, the real story is the erosion of clear communication in hiring practices.
This lack of transparency not only creates unnecessary friction in the job search process but also suggests many employers themselves may be uncertain about their long-term workplace policies, defaulting to vague language rather than making definitive commitments about work arrangements.

Skill Requirement Count By Job Category
Skill Benchmarks: Decoding the Typical Range of Requirements in Job Postings
While averages can be skewed by a few unusually demanding job posts, the real story of what employers expect is found in the middle ground. To understand this, we analyzed the "middle 50%" of job postings for each category. The chart below shows the median (the exact midpoint) alongside the 25th and 75th percentiles, revealing the most common range of required skills. For instance, a typical Software & IT role (median) lists 13 skills, but it's common to see postings asking for anywhere from 10 to 17. This data provides a clear benchmark for what's truly standard in your field, helping you move beyond averages and tailor your resume to the most likely expectations.
Top Skills by Company Size
How Startup and Enterprise Skill Demands Paint Two Different Pictures of Software Development
There's a deep difference between the technical skills prioritized by startups versus enterprise organizations. Startup-focused skills cluster around modern web development technologies and cloud-native infrastructure.
React leads the startup preference with 6.02% representation compared to just 1.03% in enterprise roles, followed closely by TypeScript, Node.js, and JavaScript.
These companies gravitate toward lightweight, flexible technologies that enable rapid development cycles and quick iteration.
The startup ecosystem also shows a strong preference for containerization (Docker), cloud platforms (AWS), and modern databases (PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis), reflecting their need for scalable, cost-effective solutions that can grow with their business.
Enterprise organizations, conversely, demonstrate a clear preference for established, enterprise-grade technologies that prioritize stability, security, and long-term maintainability.
Java and SQL dominate the enterprise landscape, with SQL appearing in 4.71% of enterprise postings versus 3.60% in startups. The enterprise preference extends to mature frameworks like Spring Boot, cloud platforms like Azure, and the entire Microsoft stack including C# and .NET.
This pattern reflects enterprise priorities around compliance, integration with existing systems, and technologies with robust vendor support and extensive documentation.
While the technical skills divide is pronounced, it's worth noting that soft skills requirements likely show less variation between company types. Both startups and enterprises value communication, problem-solving, and collaboration abilities, though the context may differ.
Startups might emphasize adaptability and wearing multiple hats, while enterprises may focus more on stakeholder management and working within established processes.
The ability to translate technical concepts to non-technical team members, mentor junior developers, and contribute to architectural decisions remains valuable across all company sizes, even as the specific technologies vary dramatically.

Communication Required in 50-72% of Jobs Across All Industries in 2025
An analysis reveals distinct skill requirements across seven major industries, with each field demanding a unique blend of technical expertise and soft skills. While technical competencies vary dramatically by sector—from Python in Software & IT to Figma in Creative & Design—communication skills emerge as a universal constant across all industries.
Software & IT - Python (33.86%), JavaScript (29.83%), and React (25.17%) are the top three most in-demand skills in Software & IT, with Python appearing in over one-third of all job listings.
Data & Analytics - SQL (68.8%), Python (60.84%), and Communication (54.51%) round out the top three, with SQL being required in more than two-thirds of all job listings in this field.
Creative & Design - Figma dominates the Creative & Design field at 61.03%, followed by Communication (53.02%) and Collaboration (47.94%) as the top three most in-demand skills.

Sales & Business Development - Communication (72.12%), Sales (34.61%), and Negotiation (16.79%) lead the pack, with communication being required in nearly three-quarters of all job listings.

Marketing & Advertising - Communication tops the list at 51.02%, showing that effective messaging is what's really required in marketing, followed by Project Management (32.05%) and Digital Marketing (24.14%).
The data underscores a fundamental shift in the modern workplace where technical proficiency alone is insufficient—communication skills have become the universal currency of professional success. Across industries ranging from highly technical fields like Information Security to creative disciplines, the ability to effectively communicate ranks among the top three requirements, signaling that tomorrow's workforce must master both domain expertise and interpersonal skills.
Top Growing Skills Overall
AI Skills Explode in Job Market as Companies Rush to Automate, Leaving Soft Skills Behind
We compared unique job postings saved in Q1 2025 and Q2 2025, extracting skill requirements from each and calculating two normalized growth measures for every skill: job-market-adjusted growth, which reflects the percentage change in a skill’s share of all postings, and company-adjusted growth, which captures the change in its share of distinct hiring companies over the same period.
The most striking finding is the explosive demand for AI tools, which experienced a 96.8% growth rate and expanded its market presence from 0.275% to 0.700% of all job postings. This dramatic surge far outpaces all other skills, with the next highest growth rates being systems thinking at 30.8%, contract negotiation at 26.1%, and site reliability engineering at 26.0%. What's particularly noteworthy is that while AI tools dominate the landscape, infrastructure and operational skills are experiencing robust growth, with observability growing 20.8%, operational excellence at 20.8%, and infrastructure-as-code expanding 14.0%. The data reveals a clear pattern where organizations are not just chasing AI trends but are thoughtfully building the operational maturity required to support these advanced technologies, suggesting that companies recognize the need for both cutting-edge AI capabilities and the foundational technical expertise to deploy and manage them reliably in production environments.
Skills Gap
To map today's skills gap, we combined two sides of the Huntr platform:
- Demand (jobs). We analyzed every public job posting created since April 1, 2025, mapping various job-title keywords into 9 broader role categories, then deduplicated by company + title. For each role, we counted how many of those distinct postings mention every hard skill (soft-skill keywords were excluded). Our analysis covered 171 distinct skills across roles, including Backend Developer, Frontend Developer, DevOps Engineer, Data Analyst, Mobile Developer, QA Engineer, Data Engineer, Data Scientist, and Full Stack Developer.
- Supply (resumes). On the same timeline, we examined "base" resumes that job-seekers built in Huntr, matched each resume's target job title to the same 9 role categories, and cataloged the hard skills users explicitly added to their profiles.
From those two pools, we calculate three key metrics for every skill within each role:
- Demand % measures how frequently employers request a given skill within a role category. We calculate it by dividing the number of job postings that mention the skill by the total number of postings for that role. For example, JavaScript appears in 100% of Frontend Developer job postings, while API skills are mentioned in 35.7% of Backend Developer positions.
- Supply % captures how common that skill is among job-seekers. We compute it by dividing the number of resumes that list the skill by the total number of resumes targeting the same role. A higher value means a larger share of candidates claim the capability - for instance, 15.6% of Frontend Developer candidates list JavaScript skills.
- Gap ratio puts the two together by dividing Demand % by Supply %. A ratio near 1 indicates balance; anything above 1 signals a shortage (employers want the skill more often than candidates offer it), while values below 1 suggest an oversupply. Our data reveals significant gaps, with API skills showing the highest ratio at 8.7x, meaning companies request this skill nearly 9 times more often than candidates list it.
The most in-demand skills with the largest gaps include API development (8.7x gap), React (8.5x gap), Java (8.2x gap), and AWS (8.0x gap), indicating critical talent shortages in these areas.
Software Development Skills Gap Analysis
Data reveals specialized infrastructure skills face 60× shortfalls in 2025, while core programming languages approach equilibrium
- Cloud platforms emerge as the most critical gap at 59.86×, with only 0.07% of developer resumes mentioning this skill despite 3.98% of job posts requiring it.
- Software development fundamentals show a 13.7× gap (10.93% demand vs 0.8% supply), indicating employers seek deeper expertise than basic coding knowledge.
- Infrastructure-oriented skills like relational databases (9.4× gap) and software engineering (8.27× gap) reveal significant shortages in backend specialization.
- Core programming languages show better balance: JavaScript (1.32× gap), SQL (1.3× gap), and Python (1.2× gap) demonstrate that fundamental coding skills have adequate supply.
- DevOps-adjacent skills like microservices (3.01× gap) and system design (3.14× gap) sit in the middle tier, reflecting moderate infrastructure skill shortages. In essence, while basic programming competencies are well-supplied, specialized cloud and infrastructure expertise represents the field's most pressing talent shortage.
Data and Analytics Skills Gap Analysis
Analytics field shows 23× cloud platform deficit while traditional skills maintain better balance
- Cloud platforms again top the gap analysis at 23.32× (4.8% demand vs 0.21% supply), highlighting infrastructure as the biggest bottleneck in data roles.
- Data engineering shows a severe 12.01× shortfall (13.35% demand vs 1.11% supply), revealing the scarcity of professionals who can build data infrastructure.
- Core analytical skills demonstrate mixed results: data analysis leads demand at 37.96% but maintains reasonable supply (11.03%), creating a manageable 3.44× gap.
- Traditional data skills show better equilibrium: Spark (1.32× gap), statistical modeling (1.42× gap), and project management (1.42× gap) indicate adequate talent pools.
- Modern data stack tools like ETL (2.14× gap) and data modeling (2.07× gap) fall into moderate shortage territory. The data reveals a clear bifurcation: while fundamental analytical and visualization skills are reasonably supplied, engineering-heavy data infrastructure roles face acute talent shortages.
Design Skills Gap Analysis
Portfolio presentation crisis hits 37× gap while core UX/UI skills face significant shortages
- Portfolio skills show the most extreme gap at 36.63× (3.66% demand vs 0% supply), suggesting candidates fail to properly showcase their work rather than lacking design ability.
- Core UX competencies face substantial shortages: UX design (3.49× gap), user experience (3.83× gap), and user-centered design (2.89× gap) all indicate high employer demand exceeding talent supply.
- Product design dominates demand at 34.6% but shows manageable supply (11.39%), creating a 3.04× gap that reflects the field's evolution toward product-focused roles.
- SaaS experience emerges as a critical specialization gap at 4.45× (5.64% demand vs 1.27% supply), highlighting the industry's cloud-first direction.
- Traditional design methodology skills show better balance: Agile (1.41× gap) and user experience design (1.39× gap) demonstrate adequate practitioner availability. The analysis reveals that while design fundamentals are moderately supplied, portfolio presentation skills and specialized product/SaaS experience represent the field's most critical gaps.

Core product management expertise faces 6× shortfall while traditional project skills remain balanced
- Product management itself shows a critical 6.21× gap (74.84% demand vs 12.06% supply), indicating a fundamental shortage of qualified product managers across the industry.
- B2B SaaS specialization presents the highest gap at 8.47× (4.09% demand vs 0.48% supply), reflecting the specialized knowledge required for modern software products
- Technical product management skills show significant shortages: AI (5× gap), software development (4.19× gap), and user experience (3.93× gap) reveal demand for technically-savvy PMs.

Specialized office skills show 4× gaps while basic software proficiency approaches balance

- Travel coordination emerges as a specialized skill gap at 3.36× (3.8% demand vs 1.13% supply), reflecting the complexity of modern business travel management.
- Microsoft Outlook shows a 3.2× gap (4.83% demand vs 1.51% supply), highlighting the importance of professional communication and calendar management skills.

Customer success expertise faces 12× shortage while traditional support skills remain balanced
- Customer success skills show a critical 12.01× gap (37.64% demand vs 3.13% supply), highlighting this emerging field's severe talent shortage as companies prioritize retention over acquisition.
- Call center experience presents an extreme 37.68× gap (3.77% demand vs 0% supply), suggesting a complete disconnect between traditional support backgrounds and modern customer success roles.
- SaaS expertise shows significant gaps: general SaaS (8.58× gap) and B2B SaaS (16.45× gap) reflect the industry's cloud transformation outpacing talent development.

- Digital marketing fundamentals demonstrate strong balance: social media (1.35× gap), content creation (1.45× gap), and growth marketing (1.4× gap) indicate adequate practitioner availability.
